*[Bug 18531] erroneous detection of writable library directories in user-namespace isolated containers*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18531>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I think this is primarily a problem of the container and not a problem of R.
Also, this particular case is easy to work-around on the user side.

Working this around on the R side could be done in this specific case, but we
would have needed some testing from you to confirm it works. It is, however,
very likely that other parts of R would run into this as well, and certainly
also other applications. While not ideal, testing permissions (writability) as
part of the semantics is an existing practice.

The algorithm used by install.packages() is different from your summary, see
?install.packages for more details. Basically, in the reported case, it is
about whether R would offer, in the interactive mode, to create a personal
library. A simple work-around would be to create the personal library
explicitly in advance in a directory that is really writable.

text:
*[Bug 17322] Installation of newer version does not upgrade existing installation, nor remove old version*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17322>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I hear many see the possibility to have multiple versions installed on the
system as a benefit or even as good practice. I am therefore reluctant to
modify the installer to even suggest to the users in any way to remove the old
version of R. That's certainly not something we would want to do just because
of the file associations for work-space files (or other registry information
used for embedding) getting lost on uninstall.

Note: there is also the package library tied to the version (not the patch
version, but the major and minor version), which the user has to handle
manually, anyway. It would often be a lot bigger than R installation itself.
Also some users install Rtools for the version of R (and again, multiple
versions of Rtools intentionally can co-exist, and certainly it is much bigger
than R installation).

On the other hand, the R FAQ for Windows has

"
What’s the best way to upgrade?

That’s a matter of taste. For most people the best thing to do is to uninstall
R (see the previous Q), install the new version, and then handle the library.
"

What most R users actually do, that I don't know.

R FAQ for Windows has some more details also on updating registry information
after installation (but that is normally not needed, and doesn't cover file
associations). <https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/rw-FAQ.html>

So, well, it is clearly a matter of taste how to upgrade, and the installer has
worked like this for decades, so users as well as tools running the installer
(even non-interactively) have gotten used to the current behavior. If there
were plans for a significant user-visible change in the installer, it might
come together also with some changes how to deal with the problem of per-system
associations and per-system registry information.

*[Bug 18252] Document how unicode strings are compared for equality*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18252>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Right, currently R isn't aware of normalization and doesn't handle it in any
way. 
I don't think this should be documented, though, because that would restrict
the freedom of what R will do in the future (also, R should primarily document
what it does, rather than what it does not).

Once we can safely assume that the proportion of R users on old Windows systems
not allowing UTF-8 as native encoding is small enough (note: some Windows
server systems still supported by Microsoft are that old), there would be space
for potential simplification of the encoding support in base R, which could be
followed by improvements in handling strings (so, Unicode strings), perhaps
including normalization. We are not there yet, and in the meantime it might
become clearer what approach would prevail in other language runtimes.

*[Bug 17639] parse() doesn't honor unicode in NFD normalization*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17639>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I agree we shouldn't be normalizing in the parser, and certainly not for
symbols. This could introduce unnecessary problems and ambiguities. At this
point when R doesn't handle normalization forms it is certainly good that
decomposed symbols are rejected by the parser - we wouldn't want two variables
with names looking the same but not being the same. 

In fact as a defensive programming rule I would only use ASCII characters in
symbol names (even though technically it is not strictly necessary in R), and
Writing R Extensions recommends that as well, see 

"Only ASCII characters (and the control characters tab, form feed, LF and CR)
should be used in code files." 

and the following paragraph. Imagine confusion with non-ASCII symbols when two
systems interact, while treating normalization in different ways.
